segments.text: This is September the 8th, I believe, at 8502 Amethyst Court.
And I have the joy and honor of chatting with Dr. Roger Feldman about his memories of being a Texas A&M for a number of years.

Roger, to introduce yourself to someone who might hear this tape or read the transcription, describe where you grew up, what family did, where you went to high school and college, experience before coming to A&M.
Well, I was born before the Depression in 1925 on a
farm in southeastern Iowa is located about 18 miles basically south of the town of Iowa City, Iowa where the University of Iowa is located.
My one great grandfather had settled in that area in 1838 and this was my would have been my father's grandfather on his mother's side and then my
Dad's grandparents on his father's side settled there in the mid-1850s.
And they began farming.
And then my grandfather followed his dad on the farm.
And then my dad and my uncle took over farming the same territory just after the end of World War II, or World War I. I went to a rural school that had nine grades in one room with one teacher.

The biggest class year we ever had as far as students in school was 33, but I was in a big class because I had six in my class all the way through from kindergarten through to the time I graduated from eighth grade.
Then I went to high school in the small town of Kelowna, Iowa, which is in the same vicinity.
At that time, it was really a very small community of only about 700 people.
Being now only some 18 miles from Iowa City, it's a little bit of a bedroom community and has grown considerably to where it's now a town of about 3,000 people and a very, very active place.
And it's centered in the Amish Mennonite part of eastern Iowa.
And the Amish and the Mennonites have both become very, very commercially minded.
Tourism is a major activity, in fact,

When Chuck McCandless was vice president and provost at Iowa State University, one of the tones that his wife had on her circle of tours for visiting dignitaries was that she would go from Ames to Pella
to the Dutch community, then to Kelowna to the Amish Mennonite community, and then to the Amanda colonies west of Iowa City, which is a German colony that was established in the late 1800s.
And that was her circle of visitation for tourists in Iowa, and it has become very much that way.
In fact, Kelowna now has become a major quilt center in the country.
They have a quilt museum, and it's a very, very active and busy community and has prospered greatly, but still essentially an agricultural community.
Went into the service in the summer of 1943 and got a medical discharge in December of 44.
Then went to Iowa State in the fall of 1945, took one year of pre-veterinary medicine and graduated with a degree in veterinary medicine in June of 1950.
And I spent the first seven years in the 50s in three different large animal practices, never really feeling comfortable in any of them.
And as a hiatus, took a job with federal food inspection in the late summer of 1957.
And one of the most fortunate incidents in my entire life happened in the spring of 1962.
I got the opportunity to apply to go to graduate school at one of five schools that the Meat Inspection Service was working with at that time.
Unfortunately, I got assigned to go to Auburn University and work on a master's degree and teach at the same time.
I had grown up wanting to be a teacher and had been discouraged from teaching by both my high school superintendent, my high school coach, and others as well.
because of the low salaries of teaching in those years.
And when I got to Auburn, I found out that I had really been a teacher at heart all my life, and it hadn't changed any.

Then at the conclusion of my master's degree program, I was reassigned to Fort Worth in the federal inspection station there, and was there for about eight months, and realized that I had to get back to school one way or another.

A Friday evening, the last Friday in May in 1965, I called a friend of mine who had once been on the faculty here and was now at the federal station at Iowa State if he knew of any places that I could apply for a teaching position.
And he said, well, I know that two people left the Department of Pathology at Texas A&M today.
And he said, I'm sure that Dr. Bridges doesn't have replacements for them as yet.

So on Monday, which was Memorial Day and was a federal holiday, my wife and my two younger children and I drove to College Station, had never been south of Corsicana in the state of Texas before in my life, and walked into Charles Bridges' office and told him I was looking for work.
That was the last Monday in May of 1965.
And 10 days after I was down here, I got a letter from him offering me a position beginning the 1st of July as an assistant professor in pathology.
I took it.
I moved here the last two days of June.
And I'm still here.
I gather that the search process consisted of Dr. Bridges.

Essentially, because the man that I had worked for, I taught for, he wasn't in my master's program, but he was the man I taught for at Auburn, had earned a master's degree here, and Bridges knew him real well.
So you think they chatted?
Yes.
Because when I left Auburn, Jim Neal told me, he said, you'll be back in school before you know it.
Let's start by your describing Dr. Bridges, your impressions of him at first and then later.
I wish in the late 60s and the early 70s that he and I could have gotten on the same page a little better.
He didn't understand me, and I didn't understand him.
I guess Ken Pierce summed it up the best.
This was after Bridges had stepped down as department head.
He said, you're different than most of us out here because, he said, you are a total university person.
And this had to do with the things I was doing in the university as far as graduation was concerned, PA work in athletics, the Memorial Student Center, and many other things.
And I was deeply involved in campus activities.
I spoke at Muster every year.
And these were things that no one at the College of Veterinary Medicine participated in other than me.
Now, in the department, he operated as the department head, not the chair.
Right.
Meaning he ran things.
Yes.
Of course, now this was a carryover from the early days of professional veterinary medicine in the academic world, where there was a very small faculty.
Most departments had no more than two or three, maybe four people in it.
And it was left to the department head to do all of the mundane work.
And the other people did the teaching.
It was that way at Auburn, and it was that way here, and it was that way at Iowa State when I was in school there.
In the Department of Pathology at Iowa State, when I was a student, there were two people.
No, three people.
There were three people in pathology, three people in microbiology, and that's all.
I mean, they did it all.
When you came here, when you joined the faculty, how many were in the department and who were they?
Do you remember?
Let's see.
There were non-students.
There was Charles Bridges, Ken Pierce, and I guess his given name is Michael Robinson.
We called him Mick, but he was in the department.
And everybody else in there were graduate students.
Gary Adams, who is now the associate dean for research, Kay Reed, and Ernest Stare were all graduate students in the department.
So there were just the three of them, because there had been five, and then the two left.
And so there was still another opening after I came.
Describe the physical
and facilities of vet school in the UK.
What was it?
The veterinary school in the summer of 1965 consisted of two structures.
The one was the academic building, which was the first structure built out there and sat by itself.
And the other was the clinic building, which housed the small and large animal clinic and the abattoir.
And they were separated by a space of probably 30, 40 feet, maybe 50 feet.
But they were separate entities.
You had to go outdoors to go from one building to the other.
Then it's either in the summer of 67 or 68 they got the grant to tie the two buildings together and enlarge the clinic.
And they did that.
And then we since then have undergone at least three more expansions.
And the department was located where at that time?
On the second floor of a three-story building.
The anatomy was on the first floor, and the dean's office was on the first floor.
Microbiology and pathology were on the second floor, and physiology and parasitology were on the third floor.
And were you given an office or a lab?
I shared an office with Ernest Stare.
What's his name?
Ernest Stair.
S-T-E-H-R?
No, S-T-A-I-R.
He was an Oklahoma State graduate, was here working on a PhD, which he completed in the late 60s.
I don't know whether it was 68 or 69.
And then he went to Nebraska, and then he subsequently ended up back at Oklahoma State where he had originally graduated.
And this will be the only dollar question I'll ask.
Your beginning salary was?
For 12 months?
For 12 months.
Describe your initial responsibilities.
What was your work assignment?
I essentially was in charge of post-mortem for the senior students.
What did that mean?

Well, that means the dissection and examination of all the deceased animals and reporting them back to the clinician and trying to arrive at a final, if they didn't have a diagnosis on the animal, try to provide one.
Most of these were the fourth-year students?
Well, at that time, it was only a three-year program, so they were the third-year students.
These were all three-year students?
Yeah, but they were all graduating seniors.
Describe some of your learning experiences since you were a new teacher, some of your learning experiences in the early years with that task.
Well, of course, I'd had a little exposure to this from my work with Federal Meat Inspection in slaughter of hogs and cattle.
The old saying, you can't tell by the looks of a grasshopper how far it can jump.
You also cannot tell from the outside of an animal what they look like inside.

It was such a shock at times in the slaughterhouses to have seen animals walking around in the pens before they were slaughtered that looked to be perfectly healthy and good for food consumption, and then to get them on a killing floor and get them opened up and find out that they were just riddled with chronic and sometimes acute disease processes.
And the same is true with...
the deceased in the veterinary school here.
In fact, I created a program that I gave to practitioners groups during, oh, this would have been in the mid-70s.

which was essentially, gee, look what I found, things that just absolutely were totally unexpected in the animal that you were examining, things that you just had no idea from the clinical reports and the clinical behavior that this situation existed.
And of course, with animals having such poor communicative abilities, if they don't really show you what's going on, it's very hard to tell.

And it was really fascinating at times to see these animals that appeared to be doing quite well and then see what tremendous amounts of pathology they could have still within them and be still carrying on a fairly decent life until they would get just to that brink of when finally they fall over the edge and then they just go down like they fell off a cliff.
Describe some of the student responses
to this experience, both the serious and the lighter?
Well, I suppose one of my most humorous incidents was that he always tried to be somewhat of a comedian at times.
And Arden Kimler, who was in the anatomy department, used to have me do the section of a horse.
for the anatomy students.
It would demonstrate both some of the warm anatomy of an animal, as well as the technique of dissecting them.
There was a fairly good sized crowd of students there that day.
Probably, I don't think the whole class was, probably maybe 30 or so of them were there.
And they were in three or four rows.
And I'm working away and talking at the same time.
And I said, now, those of you who are up here close, if you watch close, you'll notice that at no time while I'm doing this do my fingers ever leave my hands.
And I heard some guy in the back say, what did he say?
They were writing down things so fast.
Because Kemmler was a little tricky at times.
And they were taking notes as fast as they could.
And this kid didn't want to miss that.
Did anybody ever almost faint or appear shocked?
No.

By the time a veterinary student, and I presume this is true with medical students, by the time they get through with freshman anatomy, they've inhaled so much formaldehyde that they don't really get shocked by anything.
They're conditioned to the process.
As you are beginning as a faculty member here,
Did anyone ever offer you any guidance, advice, any kind of rules or suggestions?
Surprisingly so, very little if any.
And I suppose, because I had taught at Auburn, I was considered to be an experienced teacher.
I'd be my guest.
But I got very, very little, if any, guidelines in classroom decorum or anything else.
It was pretty much left up to me.
What did a veterinary faculty member wear to work in those days?
Well, in a classroom, we all wore ties and shirts.
In fact, when I retired in 1990, I can look back and say that this includes my time at Auburn and the time here.
I never met a class other than in a working lab, in a post-mortem lab, without a tie.
I just always did.
In fact, a rather humorous incident with that.
At Auburn, I was taking graduate work.
And I was in a class in German up on the campus.
And I thought this might help me in passing the German requirement for a doctorate later on.
So I took a year of German.
And one morning in class, the instructor was asking us questions in German.
And we were answering him back in German.
I was the only one in the class who was teaching, and I had on a shirt and tie.
And he asked me in German what I had around my neck.
And I very quickly answered, four children in German.
And he about went under the desk.
The other students couldn't understand why he was laughing so hard, because they didn't understand what meant, but he did.
as you are getting settled in, who became your closest faculty or staff associates?
Who'd you turn to, who were your best friends in those earliest years?
Probably J.D.
McCready.
I had a better relationship with J.D.
McCready than I did with Bridges.
Describe him.
Describe Dr. McCready.
Make believe I don't know him.
Well, I don't know whether I can or not.
J.D.
McCready was a most unusual individual.
He was a tall man, very quiet, very unassuming, but he had a way of getting his own way in this very, whatever manner, whatever it took, he got it.
But he was also somebody that I could talk to, and I did.
There was also a fellow in the department named Don Clark,
whom in later years I became very close to.
I used to visit with him a great deal.
And then a former student named James Anderson, who then spent the rest of his career in the Department of Physiology, and I were good friends, and I talked with him a lot.
The people in the pathology department were so isolated, it was kind of strange, and they still are.
They still are.
Everybody had their own thing, and they pursued it, and they didn't interact with each other very much.
You're saying that the individuals isolated themselves.
Yes, yes.
And the physiology department was a lot more collective group.
And McCready used his people a lot more group-wise.
He passed the responsibilities around and the teaching assignments around a lot more so than the other departments did.
But then eventually he had more people.
And he taught more courses.
Did you ever go to him for advice on any important matters that you recall?
What do I do about this or that?
Yes.
And one of them really created a strong barrier between Charles Bridges and I until
1976, when I finally confronted him with it one day, and things changed from that point on.
When tenure was started at Texas A&M, I was in the latter stages of my PhD program.
I had four children, and I wasn't going to get finished with the PhD by the time the seven years for tenure was up.
And I went up to McCready and said, J.D., I don't know what to do.
I said, I can't get finished in time.
There's no way that I can get finished in time.
He said, I don't have a PhD in my whole department.
And I don't have one.
I'm never going to have one.
He said, take the tenure.
And so I did.
And learned later on that that really infuriated Bridges.
He couldn't do anything about it.
He had to grant me tenure, but it really infuriated him.
And things rode along, and we just kind of ignored each other.
And in the summer of 76, there was an international food conference at Iowa State.
And there was an alumni gathering simultaneously with it at Iowa State that I wanted to go to.
So I put in a request.
to Dr. Brady's to get, I think, it was either a day's vacation, I guess it was, to attend that without any cost to the department.
And I got a real terse turn down from him.
So I sat down and I wrote him about a four-page handwritten letter.
Didn't take it to the secretary to type it.
Wrote it to him and put it in an envelope and sealed it and took it up to the department secretary and told her to give it to him.
And about 30 minutes later, he came back to my office and sat down in a chair and we talked.
And from that point on, he and I have been good friends.
And then two months later,
I ended up having a third of my right lung removed.
And I found out from someone else that he was really concerned, that he really was deeply concerned about my welfare.
But I still have the greatest respect for him because he was the one that let me come here.
And so if it hadn't been for his trust in me, I wouldn't be where I am.
And I respect him for it.
And I respect him for the feelings he had.
We're just different.
I mean, I'm different than other people in my feelings towards the university.
And so it's understandable.
People don't understand why I did commencements for as long as I did or how I did them.
But I enjoyed it.
And it was something that I found that I was doing that was useful.
And the people for whom it was being done were satisfied with it, and so I kept on doing it.
Because we're going to get to those in a minute.
Let's stay with the vet school for a second.
Who was, make believe I didn't know who the dean was in those years.
Identify him and describe him and his characteristics.
Because the first, what, 10 years, 11 years, was Alvin Price.
I never got to know Dr. Price all that well when he was dean.
I knew him a lot better after he was dean.
That's it.
Thank you.
But it really didn't get to be that bad.
It's just that particularly then after getting some domestic problem.
This is what, of course, that's inevitable.
But it was along in the 70s, which was an aftermath of, not an aftermath of this, but the problem with the isolation of the school to work is we had a real high divorce rate amongst married students.
One of the major problems with it was that when Friday night came, as I said many times, that we were very fortunate that our students only drank once a week from Friday night until Saturday night.
They just didn't have any social activities at all.
seriously taught out there, but it didn't seem to be as much of a problem.
And we still have a lot of marriages, inter-class marriages.
After they left school, which was somewhat of a surprise to me, and not either.
It's kind of like I told a couple of them one time, one of the problems with if they had wives that worked on the campus, that their wife worked in or things you've got to remember.
You're going to be veterinarians when you're
You're not.
You're competitors in a variety of ways, and you're different.
